name: Paper Chain Wall Hanging
about: We know teens love nothing more than personalizing their rooms, and wall art made from paper chains is a versatile DIY for these purposes. They can use the tutorial to get the rainbow pattern, or sketch out their own ideas on graph paper.

name: Friendship Bracelets
about: These old camp crafts are back and better than ever. See if your fingers can remember how to make spiral staircases, chevrons, diamonds and waves, then teach your kids and let them pick their own color combinations.

name: Sun Print Leaf Art
about: It's an art project and a chance to brush up on their STEM skills all at once. Gather leaves or other interestingly-shaped natural materials on an outdoor adventure, and then use them to make prints on sun-sensitive paper.

name: Tattoo-Patterned Planter
about: If you have a printer, you can get some printable temporary tattoo paper and use it to dress up old planters, mugs, pencil cups and the like.

name: Falling Leaves Snow Globe
about: Kids can make this autumn variety with foil leaves and glycerin, and then use it when they need a moment of calm focus.

name: Faux Flower Garland
about: The secret to this flower garden is cupcake liners! When it's done, kids can use them as garlands around their rooms, or as a summery table decoration for a party.

name: Jellyfish
about: Paper plates and yarn transform into these denizens of the deep. If you use glow-in-the-dark acrylic paint, you can even see their 'bioluminescence' in action when you turn out the lights.

name: Nature Craft Bugs
about: Your kids can use things they find in nature to replicate what they see in the great outdoors. The secret to this craft is using a coat of glu to make the bugs shiny (and keep the leaves from drying out).

name: Mini Lid Banjos
about: These may not sound like the real thing, but they look adorable â€” and you can dress them up basically any way you want. They're the perfect doll-sized instrument for a pretend band.
